If you're 1 mile off the ground above the north pole then which way is north and south? North should be down, and the Southpole is technically also down so North and South are both the same direction. Or another way you could determine south is with a compass. If you use a compass one mile off the ground then south will be the opposite direction of north so south would be up.
Going East and West would just result in you making infinitely small circles around the north pole so they effectively become null.
So by the 2nd definition of south you could say, you're going north 1 mile which makes you go down to the ground, then east one mile which doesn't move you and then south one mile which makes you go back up into the air one mile back to where you started.

The spool will stay in it's place:
On the one hand the string applies tension force on the spool which makes it move backwards but on the other hand the string is pulling the spool forward because it's wrapped around the spool.
The two forces cancel each other, thus the spool stays in its place.

I'm not sure the answer, but I think I have it.:
Pulling on a rope would normally make the small spool want to rotate clockwise, but the large spool will want to rotate counter-clockwise due to the reverse pull by the friction against the table.
Since both spools are locked together, their rotational speeds are the same (one revolution of the small spool is equal to one revolution of the large spool)
However, because the inner spool has a smaller linear speed (a point on it's circumference travels less distance per revolution that the large spool) and the large spool has a greater linear speed (a point on it's circumference travels farther than the small spool), the large spool's effect is greater than the small spool, and therefore it will travel in the direction of the large spool which would be towards where you are pulling.

The spool must move to the left. The only forces acting on it are the applied force (pull) and friction. The applied force is always to the left. In order for the spool to rotate to the right, friction must also act to the left, but this violates F=ma for the translational motion of the spool, since the net force will be to the left.

If the spool was rolled on its own, the large ends will cause the spool to move farther than the amount of thread it will release, so the releasing thread would get dragged with it. My initial expectation was that it would roll away, but after I thought about it, I expect it would roll towards you.

My reasoning for this is that the only stationary point that the spool is touching is on the edge of its wheel, not at the axis of rotation. Thus, when you pull on it, it's that stationary point that acts as a pivot point, causing the center that you are pulling to come towards you.

Now, if you had some weird set up with a spool whose inner cylinder had a larger radius than the outer wheels that were contacting your surface, then you could get it to roll away from you, but that's not the case here.

It helps to think in extremes, and ignore the things that don't matter. If there's no sliding, you may as well imagine the spool being a gear meshed with a flat gear track. It would also help the ignore the fact that the spool is round. Imagine the sides of the spool are gone, and we're only concerned with the center section of the spool. Now it looks like a popcycle stick with a string attached to the middle.
Now, if the string was pulling from the bottom, it would lock in place since the gears are in plane with the force, and the reaction force against the ground would equal the pulling force, like trying to topple on a flag pole by pulling it from the base. But the moment the string pulls from anywhere above the ground plane, it introduces a moment force where the spool would want to rotate back toward you. The center of the force (the fulcrum) is the ground, NOT the center of the spool. And the further up the spool you pull (such as when the reel is smaller), the larger the force trying to rotate the spool back to you. So the spool will return to you.
Edit: I just saw the answer. I love that the same exact analogy of the pole was used!

i think it will not move if the spool has larger radius than string's(as thumbnail shows). It's because when you pull the string, the pulling force(assume to the left) that will drive the spool moving backward(to the right direction) is larger than the maximum static friction on the floor. Therefore, in reality, the spool will always slipping and moves to the same direction as the pulling force(to the left in my set up). Under the no slip condition, you have to make the radius of string larger than the radius of spool so that it requires less pulling force that is smaller than the maximum static friction. Then the spool will move backwards with no slip

It depends on the friction between the rope-bundle and the "wheels" on the ground. If the friction is higher between the rope-bundle than the wheels to the floor, the spool will roll towards Dianna's direction. If the friction between the wheels and the ground higher is than the rope-bundle friction, the spool will roll away from Dianna. Even though the the wheels cause a spin to the spool, due to an even force but a longer arm , the friction will cancel is out. CONCLUSION: The answer is dependent on the amount of friction between the floor and spool, and the rope to the bundle.

Under a situation of maximum friction where the spool will constantly roll on the ground without losing traction, it would have to roll backwards (away from the direction of the pulling force). Most of the time we see it roll forwards (towards the pulling force) because the force pulling it forward overcomes the normally weak friction force the wheel has with the ground that leads to it spinning backwards at all.

My guess: If you pull with force F, the spool will experience a force F toward you - but pulling will also create a torque F*R_inner which creates a force away from you on the outer wheel (F*R_inner/R_outer). Since R_inner is always smaller than R_outer, the force away from you will be less than the force toward you, and it will move toward you with an acceleration of F/m * (1 - R_inner / R_outer)
It will not roll in either direction. It'll be stuck in its place.

The spool rolls away. Pulling the string will cause it to rotate in the direction away from you, and it can't slide backward, so it must roll forward.

The easier question to think about: if you rolled the spool on the ground, is the end of the rope going to move in the direction of rolling, or get farther behind? The circumference of the rope portion, compared to the circumference of the 'wheel' portion should give a clue. Now play that in your mind as the end of the rope is moving backwards (because you are pulling it). Also, it may help to think of an extreme case. If the rope is near the center of the wheel, how much rope will pay out as the wheel turns? What about if there is enough rope that it is near the edge of the wheel?

If the radius of the string winding is smaller than the outer radius of the spool, and the spool rolls without slipping, it will travel a greater horizontal distance than the amount of string it winds or unwinds. Therefore, the end of the string moves in the same direction as the spool if it's kept taught. Pulling also introduces a torque around the contact patch, so the spool rolls toward you.

For a simple explanation: there are 3 possibilities, so if we can rule out 2 of them we know the answer.
If the spool were to roll forward (away from the rope pulling), the friction force would need to be higher than the pulling force, making it roll backwards; this would cause it to slide, which is not allowed.
If the spool were to not move, the force of friction would need to equal the pull force; but as the friction force is more distant from the center, this would make it spin in place, which is also not allowed.
So the only result possible (under the constraint that there is no sliding at the contact point), is for the spool to go backwards, winding and shortening the rope.

Because of infinite friction, the sum of forces are = 0. So the applied force and friction force are equal.
The moment is dependant on the radius and the friction force has a larger radius, so its moment will be larger. Thus it moves anti-clockwise.

Calculations
Choose radii q<r, applied force F, friction force Ff, normal force N, friction factor u=infinity, moment of Inertia I and angular momentum a in clockwise direction.

Ff max = u * N = infinity

Sum of forces in x direction = 0 (due to infinite friction)
-F +Ff = 0
Ff=f

Sum of moments clockwise direction = I * a
F * q - Ff * r= I * a
Substitute F = Ff:
F * q - F * r = I * a
F * (q - r) = I * a

Because we only want to know the direction, the magnitude of F and I are unimportant:
(q - r) is proportional to a
But q < r -> q - r < 0 thus
a<0
Thus it rolls in an anti clockwise direction.


Alternate method:
See the ground as the centre of the rotation, so the only applied moment will be from the applied force F. This will also cause anti-clockwise rotation.

<3
I saw this riddle in a Martin Gardner book but I never understood the solution.

Unknowns: Let w be the angular velocity counterclockwise, u be the velocity of the whole spool to the right.

Knowns: Let r be the radius of the inner ring and suppose the outer ring is c times larger than the inner ring (c > 1), and the the spool doesn't slip when rotating. The string is pulled at velocity v to the left.

Inner ring: r * w + u = -v
Outer ring: c * r * w + u = 0

This solves to:
w = v / (r * (c - 1)) > 0
(spool rotates counterclockwise)

u = -c * v / (c - 1) < 0
(spool goes to the left)

Interestingly, the spool must rotate and move very quickly if c is just over 1.

I love the spool riddle. I give that one to my friends using a yo-yo. My variation of it is this.

I demonstrate that pulling the string sideways makes the yo-yo roll toward your hand. But pulling the string nearly vertically makes it roll away from your hand. I love this one because there are two ways to solve it. One is based on based on physics. The other is based on math. Of course, they both give you the same answer, but the physics one is simpler and more intuitive.

Here is my explanation for why it would move to the LEFT. If the spool rotates a full revolution, the distance it will travel is its circumference because it doesn't slip. If the spool rotates a full revolution, the string will wind ITS circumference, which is LESS than the other. If the spool rotates to the left, then the string will unwind less length then the spool travels, and will start to travel in the direction it is being pulled. BUT if the spool were moving to the right, both it and the string would move in the opposite direction of the force, which doesn't make sense!

I believe the riddle has to do with torque. The length of string that you pull induces a torque on the object in question. There is a certain angle (usual called the critical angle) at which you can pull (without making the spool slip) to make it rotate counterclockwise (making it go in the same direction you're pulling, left). Any angle less than the critical angle (as in the riddle) will cause the spool to rotate clockwise and therefore to the right.

I do love that hiker puzzle, and I've known about it for years... but wrap your mind around THIS extra complication: does "walk east for a mile" mean "keep walking towards the east every moment until you've covered a mile", or "face east, then walk for a mile in what appears to be a straight line"?

The results are actually slightly different in each case, because any apparent straight line on the globe is a Great Circle and lines of latitude are not generally Great Circles (except the equator). For example, if you face east in either hemisphere and travel in a straight line, you will end up crossing the equator.

for a movement of x to the right, the position of your hand will change by x' (r is the big and r' the small radius) to the right (=> it's negative):
alpha * r = x | / r
alpha = x / r
- alpha * r' [the amount of rope unwinded] + x [the amount of movement] = x' | + alpha * r' - x'
x - x' = alpha * r' | / r'
(x - x') / r' = alpha
-> (x - x') / r' = x / r | - x / r'
- x' / r' = x * (r' - r) / (r * r') | * (r * r') / (r' - r)
- x' * r / (r' - r) = x
Because r' is less than r, r / (r' -r) = c is negative constant
- x' * c = x
(sgn(x) = 1 if x > 0, 0 if x = 0, -1 if x < 0)
-> - sgn(x') * sgn(c) = sgn(x)
-> - sgn(x') * (-1) = sgn(x)
-> sgn(x') = sgn(x)
-> x' has the same sign as x
-> It moves to the one pulling it.

Answer I gave to Derek's video, when I was actually thinking of this riddle:

The point of contact between the wheel and the ground is the pivot (let's not deal with friction). Call it P.
Consider the line that passes between the points A and P.
If you pull along that line, the wheel would spin in place and slip. Spool doesn't move.
If you pull at an angle lower than that of AP, the force has two components: one that falls along AP (and causes the wheel to spin) and one that is perpendicular to AP (and rotates the system counter-clockwise about P). Spool moves back.
If you pull at a larger angle than that of AP, the same thing happens except that the system rotates clockwise about P. Spool moves forward.

So in this specific case, maybe counter-intuitively, the spool moves back

It will roll backward. Here is why:

If the spool were to roll forward on its own it would not be able to because the circumference of the spool touching the ground is greater than the circumference of the spool touching the string. As a result, if you roll the spool forward it will try to travel forward at a rate greater than the amount of string that it releases. This is not possible, so it won't move. Because of this you can also know for sure that if you pull on the string it will not move forward.

If the spool were to roll backward on its own it would be able to move because the circumference of the spool touching the ground is greater than circumference of the spool touching the string. Because of this, the spool would move backward at a rate greater than the amount of string that it tries to wind up. The final result would be the spool moving backward winding up some ( but not all ) of the string. Slack will develop in the string as the movement of the spool out runs it. Because of this, you can know for sure that if you pull on the string the spool will indeed roll backward. Additionally, the amount that the spool moves backward will be less than the amount that you pull the string.

It will roll toward you, in the same direction as the force pulling on it. It must because the force pushing it away at the edge of the spool due to the torque is F * (r-inner/r-outer). So the sum of the forces is net positive in the direction you're pulling. Also, just intuitively, if you pull on the inner cylinder, the spool would have to move away faster than you're pulling it toward you. It's non-sensical. Now, if you invert the arrangement so the rope is attached to the outer disk, and the spool is resting on a rail under the axle, then the force is multiplied by the ratio of the diameters, so the spool will roll away, but slower than the amount of rope you're pulling toward you.

I want to be a victim.

Think in extremes. If we assume that no sliding is possible, the answer becomes clear. If the diameter of the spool is 'S' centimeters, you will need to pull pi(S) string to make the wheel rotate once. If the outer lip L'' and inner spool 'S' are equal in diameter, the spool will not move because all the forces will balance out to result in no motion. If S≥L, pulling pi(S) string will result the spool rolling Lcm, and since S≥L, there will be more force capable of rolling, and so the spool will roll away, this assumes that the outer lip, L is on rails to allow S the be greater than it.
if L≥S, the math goes in the opposite direction, therefore pulling pi(S) string would cause it to try and roll S, distance, but the outer lip would be trying to roll L distance, since slipping is not allowed, it can't roll that way, since it would require moving more than S distance for pulling pi(S) string, which would be perpetual motion. since it can't move away, and you're still pulling on the string, the spool must either stand still, or roll towards you, Since we already determined that it stays still when S=L, the only action it can take is to roll towards you.

====Detailed explanation: =====

Imagine what happens after one rotation:
1) The rope will (un)ravel an amount equal to the circumference of the inner circle.
2) The spool will travel a distance equal to the circumference of the outer circle.

There are three possibilities to consider:
- If the spool rolls to the right, the rope will break, because the travelling distance is more than the rope can unravel.
- Similarly, if the spool rolls to the left, the rope will start to hang loose.
- The spool could remain motionless.

There are two forces: pulling force and friction force. And they are equal in size (otherwise the spool will slide).

!! The pulling force acts on the centre, the fricton force acts on the edge of the spool !!
A force on the edge of a circle causes it to rotate. A force on the centre does not.

This is why the spool will roll to the left.

===========================================
Bonus: What would happen if the part with the rope were the outside circle?

+Physics Girl It will roll towards you.

The friction provides a force equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the one you exert on the thread. But since the friction acts at distance from the centre more than the distance your force (i.e. the tension in the thread) acts. So it will experience a torque (if you are pulling from left it will be anticlockwise) which will rotate it towards you.

Another way of looking at it is the proof by contradiction. First you assume that it will roll away from you. So when it completes one rotation, the length of the thread released should be equal to the length you pulled plus the displacement of the spool which is it circumference. But this sum is obviously larger than the actual length released which is the circumference of one wind of the thread. So it's not possible. So it must roll towards you (In which case the circumference of the spool - the length you pulled = circumference of one wind).
it won't move. As the circumference of the string is small w.r.t the circumference of the spool touching the ground and there in enough friction between the ground and the spool, it will not  move.

Looking at the diagram at 3:17:
There is a leftward force acting on the spool. The spool is also against the ground, so it pushes the ground leftwards (friction). Due to Newton's third law, the ground pushes the spool to the right with equal magnitude. This force caused by the ground is further from the centre of the spool than the force caused by the string, meaning it causes a larger moment. Therefore, the net moment on the spool is anticlockwise and it rolls to the left.

the spool rolls right for the system as in the image, it rolls left instead if somehow one manages to have a spool radius which is bigger than the wheel radius.

It would move backwards, because since the torque of the whole spool is R*F,

then we get that the torque of the rolled string is the same as the "wheels?" of the spool

So,

[torque of rolled string = torque of spool wheels]

Rs*Fs = Rw * Fw

Rs -> radius of the rolled string
Fs -> force applied to the string

Rw -> radius of the wheel
Fw -> force applied to the wheel



if Rs < Rw then,
Fs > Fw

and since the force of the string is bigger than the one on the wheels the wheels rotate clockwise but the whole spool moves BACKWARDS, like if it was doing a Moonwalk...


BUT: if the rolled string was bigger than the wheels, then the spool would move forward

the spool will roll up towards the person who pulled it. This is because the force is applied between the point of contact with the ground and the axis of the spool. If for example you lay the spool on a flat railing so that the small section of the spool (with a smaller diameter) is sitting on the railing but the flange is hanging below the railing, and then pull on a string attached to the bottom of the flange, it would actually roll away from you. In this situation you can think of the spool as acting like a lever and fulcrum where the lever arm is the outer edge of the flange which hangs below the railing and the fulcrum is the point where the smaller diameter portion of the spool is contacting the railing. Pull on the lever and the spool begins to roll away from you. You could also think of this situation like so.  When the spool rolls away from you on the railing the bottom part of the flange is actually moving slightly towards you while it is below the railing. Now think of the spool rolling on flat ground.  While sitting on flat ground, every part of the spool will be moving forward as it rolls. This applies to any point on the spool including the part being pulled by the string (on the core/smaller diameter section.) So the spool will roll in the same direction as it is pulled.

If the rope is pulled to the left and the spool is to remain stationary, the spool must unwind to release more rope, thereby sliding. Sliding is against the rules so remaining still is not an option.

So we might think the spool rolls to the right releasing more rope. However, this will only release an amount of rope equal to the distance travelled by the spool. Since the rope is moving to the left more rope is required to be released, thereby requiring sliding. Sliding is against the rules so remaining still is not an option.

Therefore the only option remaining is for the spool to move to the left with the rope, rolling up the rope as it goes.

Left: force right due to rope torque = moment/outer radius, moment = force left x inner radius
Substituting for moment gives: force right = force left x inner radius/outer radius
Given that inner radius < outer radius (or inner = outer for some hypothetical magic spool with 1 dimensional string) the force pulling left will always be greater than (or equal to) force pulling right
Serial riddler 😡

Pulling left will result in the spool rolling left. There is a net force on the spool to the left. With friction preventing a slide, this pulling force will provide a torque causing the spool to rotate counterclockwise. Sumatory of momentum equals 0 if it doesn't accelerate (spinning). If you apply a force, the spool transmits a force wich generates the same momentum as you are doing pulling it. So the force of the ground is smaller than yours because the distance between the ground and the center is bigger than the one between the rope and the center.

Pulling the spool would result in it moving backwards if the radius of the string around the spool is smaller than the radius of the wheel of the spool, like the one shown in the thumbnail. However, if the spool string has the same radius as the spool wheel section, then the spool will not move at all.

If the spool cannot slide back, it will go forward when the rope is pulled.  Where the backwards tug of the rope would normally equal the force of the forward momentum and cancel each other out, the size of the outer wheel of the spool will be moving much faster than the middle of the spool will move.  So the wheel of the spool will traverse forward even though the rope is pulling backwards.
